description: Understated but very good. The owner was a little slow to seat us but otherwise the service was great. I had the California Omelette which was tasty and my son had the peanut butter pancakes which he loved.
author: Andy V.

description: I live a block away and go here all the time.  It isn't fancy-pants, but's it's just damn good breakfast food in a comfortable setting with great service.
author: Pete S.

description:
DINNER! Pat's server dinner, and it's great!

I've gone to Pats for a while for breakfast, and she mentioned that she serves dinner. 4 months later, I finally went back with a friend for dinner last night. Wow! I had the beef bourguignon and my friend had the fish. I don't remember what kind of fish, but it was taste-E.

If you live in the 'hood or are visiting, come for breakfast/brunch -- but also come for dinner!
author: Paul S.

description: Pat's cafe is cute and has good food.  I've been there three times for late breakfasts.  I've tried to go there for dinner when their website said they would be open, only to get there and find them closed.  I hesitated with a 3 or 4 stars...   I'll go with 4 because each I time I've gone, I have enjoyed my food.
author: Chloe M.

description: I thought the food was quite solid. Need to go back and refresh my memory..
author: Rob G.

description:
In a neighborhood where breakfast places tend to be either so popular that they become too crowded, or are just plain terrible, Pat's is a refreshing change. The breakfasts are excellent here, and other than recently on Sundays there is no wait for a table. You will never experience things like burned eggs here, like I have in other neighborhood places. The food is consistently good.

The wait staff is always friendly, however it appears that they are sometimes understaffed, and that leads to frazzled servers and longer than desired wait times for your food. I've never experienced any errors in orders or disrespectful behavior, however. 

Recently Pat's has expanded their hours to include dinner some evenings. In general it seemed like they were still experimenting, the nouvelle-stlye food was very good but perhaps potions were a bit small, and the lighting was turned down a bit low for my taste.
author: Jack E.

description:
My go-to local brunch place. It's really delicious (I usually get the pancake special... one pancake, one egg, and 2 strips of bacon - sweet and savory all on one plate). Friends have gotten the seasonal fruit crepe (we're talking berries... none of that melon bowl crap) and omelets and all have been happy. 

Service is also really friendly and great. 

And, the price is really reasonable.
author: Hannah K.

description: Second visit to Pat's, and it is well worth it.  Good breakfast food, nothing over the top.  I had the Eggs Benedict, and their Hollandaise sauce is perfect.  I will return to Pat's without question.
author: Chris C.

description: I agree with the prior reviewer.  Why does this place have such great reviews? Potatoes were burnt.  Hollandaise sauce was above average, but two little mean and shriveled bits of ham on stale English muffins.  Staff unprofessional.  It was like a high school locker room in the kitchen.  Bawdy conversation in Spanish, homophobic too.  No doorway between dining area and kitchen so got earful about bad oral services provided by girlfriend. Wait staff surly.  Certainly not the worse place I've been to and it might improve dramatically with more stringent supervision.  I hate crowds so this was a plus, though the lack of clientele was probably for obvious reasons.
author: Ena F.

description: Very nice. Unpretentious. A little pricey for what you get, but it is near the wharf, so one can expect that. The salmon omlette was perfect. A little more omlette and a little less bread and potatoes might have gotten a fourth star out of me.
author: Joe G.

description:
Just moved to the area and have found my go-to breakfast joint.  It's like "Cheers"; only without the extreme alcohol consumption, and the back and forth of Sam and Diane. I love that they all know my name and even remember my dog's too. It isn't quite Mama's, but doesn't have the line or wait either.

Great California Omelet.  French Toast is pretty good too. Try it with the real maple syrup. Yummy deliciousness.

Service could be a little faster; overall it's pretty good, just could be a tad faster. That's minus 1 star, but they gain it back with the little things....like giving my dog, Q, star treatment :)  Plus 1 star.  

Only star lost then is for the bloody mary.  Just a bit too thick for my taste.

Bring your dog and sit outside; they'll bring out a bowl to keep your little guy's thirst under control.
author: Courtney B.

description: I love Pat's Cafe!  It's a great little breakfast area - that we went twice.  First I had the corn beef hash, which was gooood and then I can't remember the second time what I had because I was so hung over.  And good pricing!
author: Melissa M.

description: Came here for breakfast. Using my extremely scientific method for rating a breakfast place (biscuits+gravy=...), I can responsibly report that this place is a 4. Very tasty chow with good service and a great place to sit and watch the cable cars go by.
author: Johanna S.

description: Banana granola pancakes were good. Gotta go with the real maple syrup.
author: A A.

description: Went there with a group of 5, the waiter tried really hard to seat us and we ended up outside at first. It was freezing so he happily offered to move us in to a super cute booth in the back filled with pillows! The food was amazing, everyone at my table loved what they got. Great bloody mary's, great service. Very cozy feel- i'll definitely be back!
author: Caitlyn G.

description: I went to Pat's Cafe today with my family.  Pat herself was there and she was super nice.  She was eating the oatmeal with walnuts in it, so that's what I got and it was amazing.  Coffee was great and our waitress was a sweetheart.  Everyone in my group liked our food.  We love this place.  The customers are nice too.  The interior design is very creative and artistic.  I love it!  They had all this cool artwork on the walls.  I'll be back for sure, I love this place.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
Pat's cafe is one of my local go to spots for weekend Brunch. Pat is a really sweet lady who loves to eat as much as I do. Apparently they have a new cook because the food has always been pretty tasty every time I've been. 

Try the Corn beef Hash... they make is fresh from real corned beef, none of that canned crap.
author: Thel D.

description: I loved the banana granola pancakes, with real maple syrup of course.  Also, got a chance to take some bites off my family member's plates and everything was delicious.
author: Alanna D.

description: Had corned beef scramble w/ homestyle potatoes, awesome.  Service great, atmosphere cute, cozy and friendly, attentive staff.
author: Lori A.

description:
Have been here for breakfast on several occasions, most recent being just this past weekend celebrating my wife's and my 7th anniversary.  Every time we go to San Francisco, we try and check in at our favorite little breakfast place.

Food was, as usual, fantastic.  Had the Mexican Omelet, which was truly melt in your mouth.  Also very much enjoyed the Chai Tea Latte that Pat hand made.  Even got a 2nd one to go for the walk around the Wharf.  Yes, the food takes a little while, but it is always fresh, and the help very cheerful.

So, if you are down by the Wharf in San Francisco, and looking for a great breakfast, give Pat's a try.
author: Clifton L.

description:
This place was a great call for breakfast! A fun and cute little cafe with great coffee and amazingly fresh blueberry pancakes. The real maple syrup is a treat too. 

The service was super friendly, but a bit slow; so don't plan on getting to your next appointment on time. However, the laid back energy is a nice place to savor a good home-cooked breakfast.
author: Erin M.

description: Simply put, this is a fantastic place. My family and I went here five times while visiting San Francisco and we enjoyed every meal. No matter what we got (crepes, omelets, french toast, pancakes, oatmeal, and eggs Benedict), it was all perfect. The coffee here was also the best I've had. In addition, the staff was friendly and helpful, and the atmosphere was great. Highly recommend this gem.
author: Noah B.

description: I had breakfast here with my sister and cousin. They had your typical breakfast menu like any other place. The service was quick and attentive and the atmostphere was quiet despite the restaurant being pretty full. Good experience. I'll be back.
author: Paolo S.

description: What a great experience. We had tickets to Cobb's for a Friday, 8pm show, so we decided to stop in at Pat's for a quick dinner. We walked in the door at around 6:30pm. Fun decor, love the christmas lights! Just a few tables were occupied. We took one of the window seats. As we people watched, and counted cable cars as they passed, we enjoyed the chicken quesadilla appetizer,  beef bourguignon and sonoma burger entrees, and  the creme brulee and mud pie for dessert. The whole experience was great! Food, atmosphere, company! :) It wasn't busy at all at this time of the day, there was only one waiter... but it worked out fine. We were done with our whole meal by 7:45pm. Walked over to Cobb's and were seated, with drinks, by 8pm!
author: Cster x.

description: This place is a staple for me and my friends. The food is always excellent and the staff is extremely friendly. The bacon is a little sub par but the rest is incredible. Make sure you try different pancakes here. They are outstanding.
author: Michael P.

description: We didn't want to wait that ridiculous line for Mama's and strolled further to find this place. Pat's Cafe is small, quaint and friendly. Unfortunately, I found the food medicore and would most likely not come back.
author: Lisa R.

description:
Came to this cute little place for dinner before an 8pm show at Cobbs.

I ordered the spagetti with spicy meatballs. The boy ordered the porcini with halibut. Both were delicious. I'm not even sure which one I liked more. 

The waiter was awesome too. Funny, yet professional. Attentive, but not annoying. 

Next time I'm going to a show at Cobbs, I'm definitely coming here to try the other items on the menu.
author: A K.

description: First timer.. I travel all over North America and I'll have to say the Eggs Benedict at Pat's Cafe are the best I've ever had. Home fries are perfect and what you expect! (Not frozen) with a nice watermelon slice on the side. Great coffee and friendly staff. I'll be back.
author: Kurt L.

description: My family and I stumbled upon Pat's & boy, am I glad we did!! The cilantro garlic lime fries were to die for!!! Service was a little slow but the food was worth it!
author: Linda E.

description: I love this little neighborhood cafe! Its off the beaten path, in a old school neighborhood! The food is great, the waitresses are really friendly ( a little kooky?! But cute fun people!) Its easy, relaxing,colorful and just good!
author: Miguelito C.

description: Very good food at a great price for San Fransisco. Coffee is a bit strong. Over all very good food and service.
author: Jacob M.

description: Not only is the food better than you'd cook at home, it is quicker than you can get in most sit-down restaurants.  I was told they have gotten new chefs/cooks. And she offers free WiFi.
author: George E.

description:
The review would've been higher but I had a disappointing experience today... Not only did it seem like the waitress forgot about our table for a good ten minutes at the start of service, the owner, Pat, seemed completely put off when asked to break a $20. I guess she knows a sure fire way to make sure people don't tip...

I would go back to give it another chance... While the food is fine, this is not a place you want to eat on a quick lunch break. Overall = okay.
author: DeLune Avec DeBussy B.

description:
Why? Why would a breakfast place ever need to be this bad??
Don't get me wrong...I'm not a $50 lobster brunch type. I LOVE 'greasy spoons'. But there is absolutely no reason to go here.
The food is sub-mediocre. The service is not much better. And the owner is either in the wrong line of work or she's been in this line of work WAY too long. 
I ask little of my breakfast cafes. I expect long waits on the weekends. I hope for butter-laden, artery-clogging food. But I also expect eye contact and to be acknowledged within hopefully 10, maybe 15 minutes of walking in. Not here. It seemed we were in the way.
I also expect the 'fresh squeezed' OJ to not have a Cost Co label on the jug. 
I know...I'm so needy. 
Honestly, don't waste your time here.
My quest for a good greasy spoon continues.
author: J M.

description:
i don't believe in waiting in line for breakfast. i can't justify why i would have to wait in line when there are plenty of places in san francisco that serve great breakfast. such is the case for MAMA's and Dotties cafe. i had a yearning to go to one of these places and as we did a lil a drive by the lines were wrapped around the block. inexcusable i say! i don't care how good it is because it is not like they are serving some kind of unattainable goods. whatever, i moved on so quick. 

then i found this charming breakfast place merely blocks from MAMA's near where the cable cars end. wow. no line. no tourist. great breakfast. watya know. me and the hubbie sat by the window drank coffee and tea and feasted on chorizo and eggs b.burrito and spinach and feta omelet. in addition the place is quaint and cute.
author: curi k.

description: Yummy food and decent service. Definitely worth a stop by if you are in North Beach because it is basically the best option in that neighborhood. Everything else is super pricey and not that great to boot.
author: Alissa P.

description: Ate breakfast twice there during my most recent trip to SF. Located at the Wharf, Pat's is a small "mom n' pops" type of place. It's nicely decorated and clean. I had the chance to meet Pat, and she is very nice lady. More importantly, the breakfast was excellent and the prices were fair, especially for a place located in such a "tourist trap" area. I had the crabcake eggs benedict one morning and the smoked salmon omelette the second time around. The size of the dishes was generous and they were tasty too. The wait staff ... they could be a bit more friendly. Nevertheless, it's highly recommended and I will always return there. Oh yeah, they just started serving dinner too, but I didn't get a chance to eat there for dinner (or lunch).
author: Armanius M.

description: Eclectic place slightly up from busy roads. Fun choices made with fresh ingredients and  large servings. Little gem found while in SF for our brief stay...
author: Jessica S.

description: Service slow food was cold just not a good experience
author: Steve O.

description:
This is less a review about Pat's Cafe than it is about the after-effects of Pat's Cafe. The only reason I gave it two stars is because my man likes it and because I think the location, ambience, and service are nice.

Anyway, Tuesday afternoon at Pat's Cafe, I'm having lunch, eating a perfectly delicious meal of roasted vegetable sandwich (eggplant, portabella, zucchini) and garlic-cilantro-lime french fries. Everything is yummy. Nothing I ate raised a red flag. But a couple of hours later, I start to feel somewhat queasy. So I decide not to go for a swim and instead hit the bus a little earlier than usual.

The instant I get on the bus, I smell steak, which grosses me out further. A few stops later, someone saturated with the olfactory pleasures of cigars and men's cologne sits next to me. When he gets up twenty minutes later, someone else wearing way too much floral perfume takes the seat next to me. I'm more scent-sensitive than a three-months pregnant woman with morning sickness and hotter than a cat in heat. I get off the bus a stop early, thinking I'd rather barf on the sidewalk than inside the bus on myself and others.

I don't puke, but when I get to my apartment, I open all the windows and flop onto the couch. I alternate between too hot and too cold before a friend stops by to say hi. I'm a horrible hostess; the place is a mess because I unwisely decided to put off cleaning it after I returned from Austin, and I can hardly move, talk, or listen. Once I get the dry heaves, I send him on his way.

Heaven knows how long I lie sweating and shaking on the couch before my man (who serendipitously lives two blocks away) sends me a text. I think I respond along the lines of "PLZ HALP," so he brings over some Walgreen's brand stomach-soothing pink liquid. I take some immediately and five minutes later, sweat through my clothes and quite literally lose my lunch as I had been dying to do since about 3 p.m. into the handy red bucket I keep around for such incidents. Every muscle in my body tries to aid me in eliminating the offending fibrous purply-pink stomach contents. I retch until I can retch no more, and then I experience the chills again. Once that's over, I start to think that maybe I'm in the clear. Cue three more cycles of Pepto-fever-vomit-freeze in the next hour and a half or so, and nothing is left in my stomach, so we call my health insurance's 24-hour nurse line. The nice lady asks me what happened and whether I suspect heart attack or stroke and quizzes me on my symptoms. She politely tells me to get to the emergency room or an "urgent care" facility. I babble at her about not knowing what an urgent care facility is, but she gives me a reference number to call back with anyway once I've decided on a course of treatment.

At this point, I honestly think it would be less hassle for everyone if I just die in my apartment than if I try to get to the emergency room, so I just get naked, curl into the fetal position, and sleep fitfully until the next morning.

It feels like the worst hangover ever. Also, my muscles hurt from clenching while throwing up, and my throat hurts from being the exit point. Naturally I don't go into the office; I sleep for about four more hours, wake up, and do some work from home. I eat a piece of toast and drink some orange juice and water, thinking I am on the upswing. An hour or two later, I crap my pants.

Although I am able to shower and get last night's vomit out of my hair, my well-being steadily declines throughout the afternoon. My man is a doll and brings over jello, Gatorade, tea, and saltines. I keep thinking I'm going to have another accident because my intestines are rumbling all night.

Today I have eaten jello, rice, and bean soup, all of which nauseated me and caused my stomach to make more weird noises, but at least I can get out of bed and go out of sight of a toilet. I don't know if I'll ever be back to normal.
author: Sarah S.

description: I've seen the sign many a times while heading home on the bus that I finally went with a coworker to try it out. Boy was I taken aback with the service (Go Gary!) and the California Burger I had along with the yummy cilantro sprinkled lime squeezed french fries! Now that is something I have never had! DELICIOUS!!  I would also like to thank Gary for making our (first) visit a memorable visit. Way to go Gary, I will be coming back for the turkey Club sandwich... hehe
author: Marco R.

description:
A pretty decent breakfast/lunch joint actually. I go here if I am in the mood for some eggs'n'stuff and don't have time to wait in line for Mama's or other excellent breakfast/brunch spots. There always seems to be a seat or two available. Yes, it's a bit touristy - the terminal stop for Powell-Mason line is a block away - but so what, I'm there for food and not people watching.

A couple of dishes that I like getting here are the corn beef hash and mexican omelet, which come with home-fried potatoes and enough toast to feed Paris Hilton for a week. Banana pancakes and french toast are not bad either. This place won't win any awards for imaginative or inspired cuisine, but they have good, solid, tasty food that will start off your weekend right or help you get over that hangover. Oh, and there's free wi-fi.
author: Andrei Z.

description: Such a great breakfast place.  Take the trolly and look for it on your right.  The eggs benedict hit the spot and are a winner.  They will even give you a to go cup for your coffee if you're on the run!  Enjoy!
author: Cait B.

description:
This place seems a bit touristy, while I was there, there were two parties of tourists. It must be the location.

The service was great here though, but the food was lacking. I ordered the California omelet, this had Adelle's(sp?) chicken apple sausage, avocado, cheddar and onions. The omelet was pretty bad, all of the ingredients weren't mixed in well. The avocado was a huge chunk of it, about 1/3 of an avocado, it wasn't sliced or anything, just chopped off! And the cheese was only on one side of it and nowhere else!! And the coffee wasn't really that good although it was freshly brewed.

On the flip side, the fruit cup I had instead of the homefries was great! There were sliced bananas, strawberries, blueberries and cantaloupe -- it was delicious! When the server brought out my meal with the fruit cup, she was like there's no melons in it and rushed back into the kitchen and got me another serving with melons!! How cool is that? Plus she refilled my coffee cup 3 times!! I like that!
author: Lester L.

description: Good service, really friendly staff & a vegetarian selection for lunch (did not try other meals). The food was OK.; fries had a tasty flavor of cilantro and garlic, but a little cold and the sandwiches were fine but nothing that stood out as unique.
author: Stacy L.

description: Great place, food was plentiful and delicious. After trying to get into Mama's, we walked up a few blocks and found this gem. A bit pricey, but a great spot!
author: Steven D.

description: We really like this place.  It's not the best in the city or even in North Beach -- but the excellent service puts this place over the top.  We hadn't been there for 9 months and our waiter remember us and even where we sat (and he was right!).  The breakfasts are good but the Club sandwich is about the best I've ever had (with pesto mayo) and the Turkey Cranberry Gorgonzola sandwich is great as well.  Plus the location can't be beat -- about 20 yards from where you disembark from the Bay & Taylor cable car.  I look forward to going back on our next visit.  Plus the prices are VERY reasonable for the city and North Beach.  Give this place a try!
author: Dave C.

description:
After living in SF for over 2 years, I've become a food snob including a breakfast food snob.  This is probably the worst breakfast place I have ever been to in the city.  I would take IHOP over it, seriously.

My friend offered to take me to breakfast and this place was right around the corner from her, so I said sure.  I was hungover, tired and ready to EAT!  I sure as hell didn't get that.  I ordered the French Toast thinking it would come out Dottie's style.  Oh hell no.  It was 2 tiny, repeat TINY pieces of bread.  So I said, OK, I don't need to eat that much anyways.  It was probably one of the worst French Toasts I've had to top it off.  

Also, the food is totally overpriced and service was not great.  I could have paid the same amount and received twice the portions at Polkers, Red Door or almost anywhere really.  We also waited for what seemed like forever for our food and to get our check we had to wave someone down.

In conclusion, the only reason this place is still there is because it looks cute from the outside and it's a total TOURIST trap.  Those poor tourists.  If only they knew about Yelp they could actually go and get a good breakfast!
author: Rachel S.

description:
I'm been looking for a nice breakfast place around my neighborhood, where I can find a great variety, little waiting, and delicious food. 

Many would suggest Mama's for great food... and I would give it that... but waiting in line for 45 minutes is just too much for me to handle on a Sunday morning. 

Pat's, on the other hand, has offered all that I've mentioned. They've got savory choices like omelets and benedict. They've got sweet choices like pancakes and waffles. And if you feel like a crepe or just a muffin, they have that too. 

I ordered the crab cake benedict, and boy, was that good! And the hot chocolate that I ordered, was pure heaven. 

Besides the food, our waitress was great. Very friendly and attentive. Always came back to make sure we were doing OK. 

I believe this will become one of my regular spots.
author: Maggie L.

description: A nice spot away from the tourist areas in North Beach.  You can always get some decent breakfast food here, even during lunch hours.  The coffee is good also.  It's a quite place, so a good place to take a large group and still here each other talk.
author: R L.

description: Cute place. Good food. Painfully slow service.
author: Megan C.

description: Pat is the nicest person and her staff is extremely nice.  I love this place and the food is home style, delicious, and fresh.  I love the french toast and blueberry pancakes.  Excellent prices and great service!
author: Dayna C.

description: Have always LOVED Pat's for breakfast, but went there for dinner last night and were once again more than impressed! The romaine salad was AWESOME, the soup of the day super fresh, and everything else was great as well...
author: Julia S.

description: Excellent experience. The french toast special with the real maple syrup is a treat. Perfect portion size. Highly recommended.
author: Matt B.

description: The California Crepe was so tasty and absolutely the best breakfast crepe I've ever had!  My friend had the San Francisco Omelet so that we could split and taste both entrees.  Although sounded a bit bland with only basil, tomatoes and feta, it was extremely good!  Each came with a side of delicious cajun-styled potatoes!  Gary waited on us and he was greatll!  Even though it was the day AFTER Mother's Day he gave us the "Mother's Day Special" which was a mimosa!  We were also admiring the art decorating the walls and loved one so much that we were trying to take a picture of it.  Gary saw us and brought us over a magnet replica that they had for sale!  Bought SIX of them!  Very friendly place with exceptionally great food and service!  We will return on our next visit!
author: Mattie N.

description: While trippin around the city on the 4th of July, we just happened upon this place. WOW! good food!!! Burgers were juicy and the wait was minimal. It was money well spent (tho not a lot of it! ) We'll be back!
author: Jeri H.

description:
I live around the block from this place and only discovered it recently as it is tucked off of Columbus and boy was I excited to find it.  There isn't much great breakfast in North Beach or Telegraph Hill (except for Mama's, but I have no interest in waiting 1+ hrs for breakfast) so finding this little gem filled a place in my restaurant rotation.  This is going to be my weekend breakfast spot from now on.  

Pat actually will greet you at the door (I know!  the real Pat! ha) and sit you down.  they have many options for omelets, crepes, pancakes, really any breakfast option out there.  They had seasonal pecan and spice pancakes available!  

I ordered the California omelet and it was very good.  It was served with some of the best home potatoes around, smothered in a tasty gravy...

I will definitely be coming back here next weekend...
author: Ben K.

description: Just went to this place for the 2nd time in a week.  Food is really good.  Service is excellent.  Warm and friendly staff.  Ambiance is also warm and inviting.  I would highly recommend Pat's.  When you go I hope you get to meet her.  She is quite exceptional.  Gary too, as well as the rest of the staff.
author: Cole K.

description: Excellent food and outstanding service.  Too close to Fisherman's wharf and too far from the noise. This place is a heaven when you are tired of walking all day and need a little break and they provided free wi-fi. Great food, great service and peace full what else can you ask for.
author: Jose H.

description:
We are from Vancouver Canada and whenever we are in San Francisco we make sure to have breakfast and say hello to Pat. It is a funky, homey, true San Francisco landmark. The food is great and you can relax. 

If we will ride 1000 miles on a Harley to get there I think you should check it out if you're in the neighbourhood.
- Peter & Ann
author: Peter B.

description: Great brunch, freshly cooked pancakes and lovely fresh fruit. Service great. Justifiably busy. Thoroughly recommended.
author: Janet S.

description: Fabulous dinner. What a treat. John is a gem! Hubby had a burger that knocked his socks off, while I had a nice 3 course meal...the sole was so good! Seasoned perfectly, and the clam chowder was wonderful, with a hint of bacon. Highly recommend!
author: Trxzee S.

description:
We came here for lunch after attending church in North Beach. Very friendly, warm environment. Everything was very good.

They do not have a children's menu, but we ordered fruit with yogurt for our 2 year old. The fruit was not the crappy melon mix you seem to pay $6 for everywhere else, but was a fresh medley of blackberries, blueberries, and strawberries. Plus it was with plain yogurt, not sugar laden crap we were offered at other places.

Service was friendly, albeit a little slow. We appreciated not feeling rushed although we came in just before they closed at 3 and stayed until 3:40.

A server brought over a basket of toys for our child - what a great way to keep little ones quiet and occupied. It benefited everyone in the restaurant, including us!

We liked seeing the painted cutout of pat outside which made it easy to spot her behind the bar :)
author: Catherine M.

description: Pat's beef bourguignon is an excellent dish.  Love the decor, a very homely (note: comfortable, not ugly) design, and on top of it, it is very intellectually stimulating.  The service is great, the waiter is very kindly.  Grab a window seat, open your favorite book, and enjoy the atmosphere.
author: Lukasz W.

description: We've been going to Pat's for breakfast for 7 years but we recently tried dinner for the first time and it was great! In particular the grilled romaine salad was amazing. A nice casual dinner alternative.
author: Lucas S.

description: Our family found Pat's after hiking up and down San Francisco one morning, and any place we could sit down for a quiet lunch seemed good to us.  We were pleasantly surprised when we found Pat's.  The owner (Pat, I assume) greeted us cheerfully, and immediately brought us coffee and water, which the staff kept refilled.  Our lunches were tasty and healthy.  I had the fried eggplant with veggies in a fresh pita wrap that came with a side salad.  As an added bonus, Pat's is located across the street from  the terminus of the Mason-Powell cable car line, two blocks from the Embarcadero.
author: Richard E.

description: I went back and had their new portobello sandwich, yum!!  You wouldn't say this is the most unique/original/creative food you've ever heard, but they know how to do it right and charge fairly.  2/2 positive experiences, I will keep going!!!
author: Vanessa H.

description:
A very good breakfast place!  I've eaten here twice and plan to go back often.  Extremely friendly service, great food.  Last time I ordered a belgian waffle special (ask for fresh fruit and real maple syrup).  A big fluffy half-waffle, strawberries, blueberries, and blackberries.  The bacon was decently crispy (I like crispy bacon).

Why the low reviews from others, then?  Well, maybe the place has turned over a new leaf in the last few months or something, and they're trying to repair their reputation.  When I went there about a month ago, the place was pretty empty and they were extremely friendly and attentive.  They were thrilled to hear that I was a local, and encouraged me to come back.  (I've only been to Mama's once, but they seemed to take their customers much more for granted.)  I'm also a person of simple tastes, and maybe others want something fancier.

As for the french toast, though, it is indeed made with crusty french bread (diagonally sliced).  I haven't tried it, but I saw someone order it, and I could see how it would be unexpected.

In closing, forget the negative reviews and give this place a shot if you're in the area!  Note: they close at 2:30pm.
author: David G.

description:
Maybe it was the state of delirium I was in from the all night binge fest that  occurred the night before, but nothing hit my alcohol soaked palette better than this small little breakfast joint in North Beach.

We were greeted by Pat and seated immediately, if this place had been on polk st. or chestnut  I wouldn't be writing this review today as we would still be waiting.  Needless to say, I was impressed.

The service was little slow, but the food was worth the wait.  I had the California crepe, which was fantastic.  The home fries served with it were a little dry (probably because I was dehydrated).  The prices were reasonable, the portions were well sized and there was a solid breakfast drink menu as well, which kept the fun rolling from the night before.  The other dishes my friends had looked awesome, especially the fluffy blueberry pancakes.

I can't say I would make the trip up from San Bruno to go again, but if I'm in the city in the morning, I'd definitely head back, hungover or not.
author: Ken P.

description: This place is really cute. It's very homestyle cooking in a very cute cafe. They have free wi fi which is a plus.
author: Crystal M.

description: Cute place but kinda small. Took a while to get our grab...staff was nice. Maybe I'll try again if I'm in town.
author: Arnisha W.

description: Absolutely the perfect little spot off the beaten path for a GREAT breakfast.  I had the California Omelet with wheat toast and a very good coffee.  The avocado in the the omelet was very refreshing and lightened up the whole dish.  All the ingredients were extremely fresh and the staff were simply great, friendly and attentive but not annoying and intrusive.  Do yourself a favor and chose this great spot over the tourist traps on the Wharf and you will not be disappointed.
author: Rob J.

description:
Overrated. Food quality at best is on par with IHOP or Denny's.

Buttermilk pancakes were very poor with a chemical/processed taste. Nothing fresh here. Scrambled eggs with flavorless and rubbery.

I'd suggest going somewhere else.
author: Steve S.

description: After walking around Fisherman wharf looking for a good place to eat breakfast (that was reasonable priced) my girlfriend and I stumbled into this place.  We decided to walk a few blocks into a less tourist populated area.  We were both starving and wand wanted breakfast.  When we walked in they handed us breakfast and lunch menus (really stoked because it was about 2pm.)  I ordered the California omelet and was very pleased.  It was a little different than what I am used to, being from San Diego, California omelets usually have carne asada.  This was still really good!  I was also very happy with the coffee.  Most breakfast cafes have very mediocre coffee but this place had a very good coffee, I was not expecting that.  On top of the food, the service was also very good.  The staff was very polite and "on-it"  Overall, I would recommend this place and if I am back in that same area again I will go their again.
author: Ryan D.

description: Sis and I have been here many times since our initial visit in 2009. I have even come with friends.... while the food and service is good, when it gets busy in summer, as can be expected, things can be forgotten. Tonight I ordered a fish and chips and while it was served quite quickly (at almost 6pm on a Friday there was nobody else), the fries were so thin it wasn't even shoestring, and the fish itself was four formed-pieces that were so commercial that I wish I hadn't ordered it. If you come here, pass on the fish and chips or you'll be very surprised and disappointed. Pat's used to give a native SF discount (show proof of SF residence) but they stopped it a few years ago, saying they were working with Yelp to give a discount but that never seemed to materialize....  remember if you order tea, it comes in a big wide mug BUT it's w/o refills (not even water). The art within is worth a look-see though and think as of today there are four or five artists on display.
author: Tony L.

description: Excellent spot for breakfast. Beats the heck out of all the junk along Fisherman's Wharf.  Worth the short walk if you are staying at any of the hotels near the wharf.  We found it by accident when we decided to walk up Columbus Ave. looking for breakfast.  The Breakfast choices were large and the service was good and friendly. They also offer lunch and dinner.
author: Tom K.

description: I've been to Pat's twice now - once as the hung over me, and once as the peppy me while my parents were visiting me in SF.  Both times, Pat did not disappoint!  It's a great place to go for a greasy, delicious breakfast / brunch - sweet and savory dishes, and you can get a little hair of the dog if you need it.  Banana granola pancakes rocked my world.  The Eggs Benedict is my guilty pleasure.  Their lattes are also fabulous.  Seating area is small and it can fill up fast, but if you are a planner, you can make reservations.  Both times I went, we had a party of 4 people, and we only waited about 5 - 10 minutes to be seated.  There is currently a Scout Mob deal at Pat's, but it expires soon.  Pat is usually there, greeting and seating guests herself.  Service can sometimes be a little inattentive, but not the point where I feel it takes away from the meal.  Probably my favorite breakfast spot (so far) in SF.  Go check it out!
author: Jenna C.

description: Great spot for your basic breakfast options. Cute atmosphere and reasonable pricing.
author: Nicole L.

description: Great soy latte and my hubby enjoyed the eggs, toast and hash browns. Wonderful service and refreshing for San Fran!
author: Kassandra M.

description: Consistently decent breakfast spot.  Out of the way enough that it attracts more locals than tourists.  The breakfast is good but not great, well-portioned, and the coffee is pretty good.  The service is fine.  The atmosphere is pretty cool, with interesting pictures on the walls.  Overall a solid place but I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here.
author: Geoff K.

description: Came here on a Saturday morning with two friends and a toddler. There was no wait since we were okay sitting outside on the slightly windy and colder morning. The manager said we had to order inside when we were ready which I thought odd that he couldn't send someone to get our order in a couple minutes. Not a big deal but a but strange in my opinion seeing how there was someone who checked up on us occasionally after we got our food and refilled out coffee. I ordered the Mediterranean crepe and my friend got the California crepe while the other just got a blueberry pancake. The crepes were ok, we both thought an egg dish would have been a better choice. The home fries were on the saltier side with no herbs on them.  I would come back again to try something heartier than a breakfast crepe. I wanted something light that morning and my Mediterranean crepe was light but nothing special on taste.  Less than $40 for all three meals and two coffees.
author: Bling L.

description: My daughter and I have decided to make San Francisco a tradition for our annual girls weekend primarily because we want to keep going to Pat's for breakfast.  Hands down the best biscuits and gravy we have ever tasted! Great ambiance and just simply a fantastic place.
author: Melanie V.

description: Good diner/cafe. The menu is similar to Mel's just not as sprawling. The specials are where its at though. The corned beef hash ($10, with eggs and potatoes) was great. I also had a bite of the salmon scramble with feta and basil, which might have been better than the hash. Pat seems nice...
author: Nicolas H.

description: We ate here 4 days in a row. Great, fresh yummy food. Love it for breakfast! It was always full but never a wait.
author: Kristin B.

description: Pst's cafe has been our favorite spot for breakfast. But now we go back over and over again for their DINNER. The special salmon was so good. Crusty on the top but melted in my mouth. Haven't had such good salmon for years. I told Pat this should be in the regular menu. My husband liked the pork tenderloin. He felt like to have more even though his stomach was full. Not only the staff, the dinner prices are also very 'friendly' for the quality. They open only Wed. to Sat. evenings for dinner. Wish they can open every evening.
author: V L.

description: Well I like Pat's. I've been twice and each time I can say that the food was quite good, the price factor was not out of step with the neighborhood and the service was friendly and down-to-earth. I do remember thinking the first time I was  there that the salad I got with my sandwich was exceptionally good.
author: Jesse C.

description: Super quaint and quirky neighborhood spot.  We go for there now and then for breakfast and it is always good and the staff is really nice.  Last time though, I got a veggie burger with fries, which was good but I would forgo the vinegar garlic sauce if they give you the option (it really just makes the fries soggy).
author: rhiannon g.

description: They had the best pancakes I have ever had and yes I have tried a lot of pancakes! Honestly, if you are a pancake lover you must try these. The food here looks wonderful. This was my first time here and I am spreading the word and will be back ASAP! The service was excellent. Cheers!
author: Dave H.

description: So-so.   Blueberry pancakes were delicious.  My nephew's eggs were way runny tho and he didn't care for the sausage gravey - and he does lke sausage gravey generally.  Biscuits were just okay. Home fries were bland. Had better breakfast other places.
author: Lucy A.

description: Nice and quiet location, good service, walking distance from wharf hotels and trolly locations. Service is good, but a bit slow. Don't expect an in and out breakfast, but the meal will be well done!
author: Preethum P.

description: Tried this place when the boyfriend and I didn't want to walk up the hill to Mo's in the rain.  I had the Bisquits and Gravy which were pretty damn good.  Cozy and clean atmosphere and really nice staff.  I didn't see any tourists but I live in the area so I think I'm immune to them by now.
author: Francis M.

description: Located between North Beach and The Wharf.  Pat's is a homey tourist spot.  It's a place where the owner hangs pictures of her cat by the register and where visitors send postcards to Pat from far flung regions.  The sandwiches are fine.
author: T-Bone L.

description: I love Pat's Cafe! I've only eaten breakfast there, so I cannot comment on their other meals, but the breakfast is really outstanding. On a recent trip to S.F., I had their California omelette several times. They use chicken sausage and avocado, and the eggs are very good quality. The potatoes had a good home cooked feel. The coffee was rich. On other occasions, I've gone for the ham for breakfast. A really tasty slice. The service is friendly and efficient. There is a variety of local artwork on the walls. I believe some of it is for sale, some may not be. In general, the decor is attractive.
author: Grant L.

description:
Meandering back to our hotel from North Beach, I was happy to find a local cafe mere blocks from Fisherman's Whoref that appeared to be a nice break from the touristry and chaindom that reign in the area. It was close enough that I figured I could make it there before I killed someone in my pre-caffeine morning grog-rage, so I decided to try it out.  

The decor was cute (despite some crap art on the wall), and they offered a couple of tables outdoors. The server was prompt in bringing us menus and coffee. Mmmm, my caffeine fix...*gag*! The coffee was vile! It tasted like someone had ashed in it. (Yes, as an ex-smoker who likes her drink, I know *exactly* what this tastes like.) Not a good way to start off a meal. It was so undrinkable I considered leaving, but feared for the lives of passersby, so conceded to eating something first. 

I was delighted when the plates arrived with a slice of decorative watermelon. The food did not deserve such grace, however. The crepe I had was too sweet for the contents; it tasted like a maple-syrup pancake, clashing with the cheddar, mushrooms, onions, and chicken sausage inside. Perhaps they were trying to capture the imagination of McGriddle fans. The veggies tasted like they'd been resting on the grill all morning: limp, with the flavor all burnt out. The home fries were ridiculously greasy and it was obvious they'd made a few rounds on the grill. In fact, they tasted like you were eating grill-scrapings moreso than potatoes. My companion's French toast combination featured two tiny slices of baguette with the eggs and sausage. It tasted fine, but nothing I couldn't concoct in my own kitchen in thirty seconds or less: there was no spice or additional flavor to contribute to the eggy taste. 

Service was fine, but the meal was incredibly underwhelming. It's sad when the decorative watermelon slice was the best tasting part of your meal. Another note: they offer free WiFi, but that seems meaningless in the context of their shite coffee. I don't see this place lasting long.
author: Mary R.

description: Yum. Best crabcake eggs benedict I've had. And I love my eggs benedict. And I love my crabcakes. Eggs arrived warm. Hollandaise had a little tang and was not too thick that it overwhelmed the eggs, crab, or english muffin. Crab cakes were crispy and tasty. English muffin was lightly toasted. It came with delicious home fries and a slice of watermelon. It cost about $13 and was a great deal. Coffee was fresh and strong. I stumbled across the place while taking a detour while walking to Trader Joe's. They're a couple of blocks up from the cable car turn around on Taylor Street -- right where Columbus and Taylor intersect. They are NOT easy to find. The interior is bright, clean, and fun. I think the owner is also an artist and her pleasant photos (and a couple of paintings, I think) line the walls of the cafe. I look forward to returning for a different meal.
author: Bubbles L.

description:
If I could give ten stars to Pat's I would. My finace and I live up the street and after only six months of living here, I think we've eaten there about 20 times. The breakfast is phenomenal. Not to mention the friendly staff and the famous Pat. 

Highly recommend the California crepe, the pancakes and the eggs benedict.
author: Danielle E.

description: Came here for dinner last night after passing by it many times and always thinking how inviting it looks on the outside.  The inside is far bigger than the outside would have you imagine, one of those rectangular spaces.  We ordered the soup of the day, a chicken chowder and the calamari salad.  Both were excellent.  The soup was so tasty and jam-packed with a variety of ingredients.  The salad has such flavorful dressing and the calamari was seared to perfection that it was hard for us to swap the dishes after we've eaten half the portion, as is our usual custom.  We also ordered the grilled vegetable entree and a side of mac and cheese.  No complaints with the man-n-cheese.  But the entree was disappointing.  The vegetables were actually boiled rather than grilled.  The polenta cake that came with it was totally bland and the sauce that was underneath it all did not add anything to the dish.  Overall, a place I wouldn't mind coming back to again, and soon!
author: Yvette F.

description: Pat's is pretty decent for breakfast but something seems missing.  I recommend the waffles and a coffee.  If you don't want to pay the hefty price and wait of Mama's then head over to Pat's Cafe.
author: Buddy R.

description: This place was recommended by a friend--what a find! We were seated (party of 5) almost immediately, and on a Sunday morning. That's a rarity at most weekend brunch joints in SF. Great brunch menu. I highly recommend the Pecan Pumpkin Spice Pancakes. Very kid-friendly place; our friend's 4-year-old loved it. Fast service and great prices.
author: Anne M.

description:
disgusting and a tourist trap.  stay away.

did i mention its a tourist trap and to stay away?
author: Jen H.

description: This place has become my favorite place for breakfast.   The staff super friendly.  I can almost always find seating on the weekend around 11am for brunch after the rush and so far everything i have had is excellent!   The hollindaise for the eggs benedict has to be one of my favorites, and the spiced pancake divine, but definitely get the real maple syrup!
author: David J.

description: My default breakfast spot. Usually a short wait for a table if at all. The staff is friendly, the food is inexpensive, and if you're lucky you can sit in the corner booth and play with the fuzzy pillows.
author: Howie M.

description: Good food (nothing spectacular but decent), great coffee, friendly service, and a cozy atmosphere.
author: J K.

description: After breakfasting at Pat's Cafe on our way TO work this morning (chosen to try the 'banana granola pancake'), it was so good we decided to go back for dinner AFTER work.  We could repeat this pattern every day until we'd eaten everything on the menu - then we'd start all over!   We were totally amazed at the uniquely different flavors and quality of the shrimp quesadilla and short ribs served with a truly delicious potato salad, topped off with an apple tart that erases all memory of previous ones.  Service was friendly and perfectly timed - this unassuming cafe will blow your socks off!
author: Kathy C.

description: The woman working was very nice and offered to hang up my friend's art to sell even though we were from across the country. The menu was good, I had banana granola pancakes and eggs. The oatmeal looked delicious with a lot of fruit. On the weekend they have brunch specials with mimosas and screwdrivers. It was a laid back atmosphere. Get a table by the window and watch the cable bars go by.
author: Kristin L.

description:
We first ate breakfast here last year, when I had possibly the best Joe's Special I've ever eaten. A few months ago we moved into the neighborhood (practically across the street from Pat's) and have been back several times for breakfast and dinner. The food has always been good and sometimes excellent, but the service is pretty consistently slow. I don't know if it's the waitstaff or the kitchen, as most of the delay seems to be between ordering and getting the meal; though we've also had to sit and wait quite a while for our check.
Unfortunately, our last visit several weeks ago really ruined it for us. Pat, the owner, and some friends were celebrating the unveiling of a new sign in front of the restaurant. After they left the man who had been working on the sign had a loud and long disagreement with our waiter. The man stormed in and out of the restaurant several times, slamming the doors to his Jeep, shouting at the waiter, and probably frightening his poor dog which was in the Jeep. At one point he drove off only to return a few minutes later to continue the antics a bit more before leaving again. Our waiter did apologize after the first outburst but it then continued and yes, we waited at the table after our meal for at least ten minutes before the waiter reappeared and we could ask for our check.
So: good food, located very conveniently for us, and we probably won't be back. If we wanted a floor show we would have ordered it. Perhaps employees shouldn't drink where they work.
author: Steve J.

description: Dinner at Pat's is great food and a great deal -- about 20% less than eating anywhere else in North Beach for the quality. We live in the neighborhood, and took some friends there Monday night.  Sadly, it was almost empty.  While breakfast and lunch are waiting lines only, more people need to discover Pat's for dinner or she won't be able to continue being open at night.  We all loved the pork tenderloin, grilled calamari salad, and the garlic cilantro fries are great.  The atmosphere is colorful and really delightful with all the original framed art -- it's like eating in a gallery.  Best of all, it's quiet -- no high-ceilings, music blaring.  You can actually enjoy the company of the people you're with.
author: Jeanie S.

description:
Pat's Cafe is a cute little restaurant. Good for breakfast and lunch, not sure about dinner. I found it extremely odd that despite eating there every single Saturday for over a year, Pat had and still has no clue who me or my husband are yet she frequently greets the other regulars. That aside, the wait staff always knew who we were and brought out our usual drinks right away, while Pat wandered around kinda spaced out. 
When busy the service is understandably slower, but overall it's really nice.
author: Kathleen b.

description: my brother and i went here per Urban Spoon's recommendation. cute little place, parking was difficult but where isn't it in this city? we got a table in the window and watched the cable cars go by as we ate our breakfast. i got the fruit crepes which were verrry good. fresh bananas, blueberries, blackberries and strawberries. none of that fruit compote some places give you. my brother had biscuits and gravy which he said were good. i'll have to take his word for it...the juice tasted fresh and the the prices were reasonable. the service was also really good. our waitress was very sweet and the hostess (maybe pat herself?) was super friendly. i would love to go back.
author: Melisa B.

description: Hands down, the BEST tuna melt i've ever had in my life!  Wow!  It's an experience.  And not to mention, the friendly staff and great service.  You rock, Pat!
author: Rebecca A.

description: Small place. Greattt food! Very healthy and fresh selection. Probably one of the best omelets I have ever had. A little understaffed but worth the slight wait.
author: Andrew R.

description: I just had dinner here for the first time and was delighted. A very interesting menu with several great choices. I had the polenta with gorgonzola and grilled vegetables, and my friend had a beautiful creme brule. A real find...cozy neighborhood feel with great service and very high quality cuisine. Good wine list as well.
author: Janice W.

description: Pat's Cafe is ever as good as any of the North Beach restaurants for a great dinner. The quality of the food is excellant and beautifully presented. The wine list is a good one and pairs nicely with the menu. If you need a break from the North Beach Italian or the Wharf's fish food, go to Pat's. The menu is comfort food with a gourmet flare. You can hear yourself talk and many evenings can meet some nice people from the neighborhood or visitors from other places. Parking is limited due to location, but it is on the Cable car line for Mason/Powell or the 30 Stockton stops just a block away. The 47 VanNess stops at Jones/Northpoint and then walk up two blocks to Pat's. After dinner take a stroll down to the Wharf to walk off the yummy desserts!
author: Laura G.

description: I am torn- I really want this place to succeed because it's so close to my apartment, but I have to admit that the comments here are right on. There are a couple of economic factors- note I don't know her rent, or the real flow of business there- that must determine some decisions. The breakfast spots farther down Columbus are worse quality, and in the same price tier. So if you're visiting from elsewhere, and you're not a foodie, then you won't mind. SF has an expensive reputation, etc. It's just not on the price/quality calibre as the rest of the city. Mama's is tough competition, and they have a big following, but luckily the line makes the decision for you. I usually hike a few blocks to Divine for no line, and equally good food. I would suggest to Pat that she stop trying to compete with the tourist stuff on Columbus (near the Cannery) and try to compete with the better fare of upper NoBe. How? Slim down the menu, specialize, create some interesting dishes, de-homey the place a bit ... that really makes it more inviting in my mind. Check out  Ella's, and Divine for some clean, spare, but inviting decor and processes. The tough bit is that the space is very narrow, with little light, and that effects the inviting factor: introduce sidewalk dining (will get the cable car guy sin!) and once you do all this, circulate a flier to neighbors about some birthday deal, or 10% off (Curry House & Fior D'Italia did this). good luck pat.
author: Anna B.

description: It's been a back and forth relationship with Pat's but I have to say their breakfast is good.  The menu selections suggest that you are actually in San Francisco and the wait staff is consistant and nice.  Sometimes it's a little slow but it's usually nice to sit back and relax for a while.  Pat the owner is there almost everytime we go, she remembers us and our son and is always pleasant.
author: Robert A.

description: mmm..it's alright.  that pretty much sums it up. Nothing special nothing horrible.  Just meh.
author: Allison M.

description: solid 3 stars - good food, good coffee, but nothing too special.  its a good local spot for breakfast, but not necessarily a go-to spot for me.  the staff there is really nice though, the service is good, and the price is right!
author: Carolyn B.

description: We had been here for breakfast a few times in the past and found it okay, but hadn't been here recently.  I think after today we probably won't be coming back.  Our waiter come over to our table after about 2 minutes to ask if we were ready to order.  I'm not sure if most of the diners here are speed readers or what, but I hadn't even finished reading the menu yet.  Once we did order, I went with the oatmeal in an attempt to be healthy.  Oatmeal is one of those things that should not be hard to get right.  What arrived was the driest, most flavorless bowl of oatmeal I have ever seen in my whole life.  Blech.  My fiance had a crepe, which he liked okay but thought was not hot enough.  Our friend was the lucky one on this outing and liked his food just fine.  I'm taking away some additional stars for service though.  After he dropped off our dishes, our waiter never returned to our table to ask if everything was okay or if there was anything else he could get us.  After I actually dug into the oatmeal, I was really wanting some butter or water or some sort of moisture.  Eventually I ended up resorting to using whatever cream-like substance (half & half?) was on the table for the coffee.  Um, yeah.
author: Squirrel L.

description: Super Friendly and great service. The food does not dissapoint.
author: Pier I.

description: Pumpkin pecan pancakes were amazing!  Reasonable prices and friendly service.  I was worried about it being too touristy due to the close location to Fisherman's warf but definitely a great place for locals too.
author: Krystal D.

description: This quaint little cafe close to Fisherman's Wharf and North Beach is the only place I would even consider eating breakfast. Not only is it always an out the door wait at Mama's, but you have to order at the counter, and service is minimal. Pat's has very comfortable decor, the service is usually prompt, unless the place is packed, in which case the wait is minimal. Pat's has all the usual breakfast food; a wide selection of omelettes (their specialty), waffles, french toast, a variety of pancakes, but also offers a tantalizing lunch menu; Sandwiches (with vegetarian options), Soups, Salads. The food, in my opinion, is just as good, if not better, than Mama's, but your overall experience at Pat's will be much more personal and cozy than any other breakfast place I've been in the city. Whether you just come in for a coffee (and their espresso is excellent), and a chat with the owner, Pat, or come for a group lunch, Pat's won't dissapoint. Don't let the best kept secret in North Beach stay a secret.
author: Mona K.

description: My friend and I were looking for a decent priced/good food kinda place when we stumbled upon Pat's Cafe. Thinking that it was a coffee shop we went inside we were greeted by a very nice woman. They informed us that they just started serving dinner. So we sat down in the back and ordered our food. The food was great my friend got the hangin tender and I had the beef bourguignon both were delicious perfectly cooked and we had great service. We had creme brulee and the owner treated us to some lattes...very nice of her (Thank you!) So if you want a great place for breakfast, lunch of dinner this is the place to go for good priced, delicious food!
author: Lita L.

description: the chai latte  was really good.   food was ok. there are some restraunts where the food on the menu sounds bizare, but you trust the chef and the combination tastes amazing. and some places like this one where the food is exactly as it sounds on the menu. so, my point; the food wasn't great.
author: Josh B.
